channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Caught Between Protesters and Israel, Palestinian Security Forces Shift Tactics
item.description: Amid violent protests in the West Bank, a longtime security alliance with Israel may be redefined in the face of public anger and mistrust.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and RAMI NAZZAL
item.media:description: Israeli security forces at a checkpoint near the West Bank town of Jenin. At one time, Palestinian security forces worked closely with their Israeli counterparts, but that coordination is shifting.

item.title: Lessons of Past Disasters Helped Mexico Sidestep the Brunt of a Hurricane
item.description: The country had no immediate reports of deaths or damages to major infrastructure, a result that experts attributed to a combination of luck and planning based on past disasters.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN and ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arturo Cortez Mendoza replanting a fallen palm tree in Jalisco State. No deaths were immediately reported from the storm.

item.title: Mexico Spared Major Damage by Giant Storm
item.description: President Enrique Peña Nieto said there were no initial reports of deaths but the danger was not past. “We still can’t lower our guard,” he said.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family at a bus station in Guadalajara, where they arrived from Puerto Vallarta after fleeing Hurricane Patricia.

item.title: Amid Splits, Catholic Bishops Crack Open Door on Divorce
item.description: Pope Francis called this assembly to reconsider the church’s approach to marriage and family at a time when the very definition of family is changing.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the conclusion of a synod of bishops, at the Vatican on Saturday.

item.title: Jailed Ex-President Lingers as a Force in Ivorian Vote
item.description: For now, President Alassane Ouattara’s chief challenge is keeping the peace on Election Day, the baseline needed for any future economic gains.
item.dc:creator: SASKIA DE ROTHSCHILD and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: Supporters of President Alassane Ouattara at a campaign rally in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, on Friday. His predecessor, Laurent Gbagbo, faces trial but retains a following.

item.title: Norway Has a New Passion: Ghost Hunting
item.description: Belief in ghosts has been around for centuries, but they have now found a particularly strong following in highly secular modern countries like Norway.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Furniture is stacked inside the tower of Refsnes Gods, a luxury hotel on the outskirts of Moss, Norway, that some locals believe is haunted.

item.title: Charlie Hebdo’s Recovery From Attacks Opens New Wounds for Staff
item.description: In the nine months since gunmen killed 12 people at the satirical paper’s headquarters in Paris, a surge in readers and revenue has divided employees.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Parisian holding a recent issue of Charlie Hebdo. Readership has jumped tenfold since the paper was attacked in January.

item.title: Cardiff University Rejects Bid to Bar Germaine Greer
item.description: Officials at Cardiff University cited the importance of free speech after rejecting a student petition to ban a campus lecture by the feminist author Germaine Greer.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: South Korean Plastic Surgeons Help Northern Defectors Erase Their Scars
item.description: Dozens of defectors from North Korea have signed up for a free surgery program, including a woman whose face was scarred in a factory accident and a man who cannot breathe through his nose.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Hong Jeong-geun uses a laser to remove a tattoo from the arm of a North Korean defector at a clinic in Seoul, South Korea.

item.title: One Village Mourns Dozens After Bus Accident in France
item.description: Most of the victims from the fatal collision were from Petit-Palais-et-Cornemps, a neat low village of about 600. Everybody here knows, or is related to, someone who died.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Most of the victims of the fatal bus collision on Friday were from Petit-Palais-et-Cornemps, France, a village of 600 in the southwest. Residents plan to gather for a march.

item.title: Israel and Jordan Agree on Steps to Ease Jerusalem Tensions, Kerry Says
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said Saturday that Israel and Jordan had agreed to take steps aimed at defusing tensions at one of Jerusalem’s holiest sites.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: General to Investigate U.S. Airstrike on Doctors Without Borders Hospital
item.description: The death toll in the bombing raid on a Doctors Without Borders Hospital in Kunduz has risen again, and civilian casualties have been confirmed.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Election Will End Kirchner’s Presidency, Not Her Hold on Argentina
item.description: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner’s machinations while in office ensure that she will continue to exert her sway over the country’s future.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina, at the United Nations last month, has maneuvered to exert her will after her two contentious terms end.

item.title: Opinion: With G.M.O. Policies, Europe Turns Against Science
item.description: An irrational phobia of genetically modified crops is causing real harm.
item.dc:creator: MARK LYNAS
item.media:description: A cornfield near Roquettes, France, after hundreds of activists uprooted genetically modified plants to replace them with organic ones in May 2014.

item.title: Dispatch: France’s Wrinkle in Time
item.description: Based on its location, the country should be in a different zone.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN

item.title: Voice Is Sought at the Vatican on Remarriage
item.description: A question of how far bishops will go in backing Pope Francis’ call for a church more open to the complicated, less-than-perfect lives of modern Catholics.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis posed with African bishops and cardinals during a morning break in a conclave in Vatican City on Friday.

item.title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Attack in Bangladesh
item.description: The explosions Saturday morning during a procession in the capital were the third act of violence that an Islamic State account has claimed in Bangladesh in the last month.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: Hurricane in Mexico Downgraded to Tropical Storm Patricia
item.description: The hurricane, which meteorologists called the strongest recorded in the Western Hemisphere, toppled trees, triggered landslides and tore off roofs as it slammed into the coast.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN, AZAM AHMED and FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: An employee boarded up a store in the Pacific coastal resort of Puerto Vallarta on Friday. The rapid strengthening of the storm caught many people off guard.

item.title: World Briefing: Bangladesh: Blasts Strike Shiite Procession in Capital
item.description: At least one person was killed and dozens were wounded during an event on the holy day of Ashura.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Jimmy Carter: A Five-Nation Plan to End the Syrian Crisis
item.description: The United States, Turkey and Saudi Arabia should join with Russia and Iran to develop a peace plan for Syria.
item.dc:creator: JIMMY CARTER
